head.title: No Tricks For Army At Home

identified-content.org: United States Military Academy (West Point, NY)

hedline.hl1: No Tricks For Army At Home

block.p: Maybe Army should have reverted to the wishbone against Boston College today in the Black Knights' loss at Michie Stadium.

Maybe Army should have reverted to the wishbone against Boston College today in the Black Knights' loss at Michie Stadium.

Unveiling in its home opener a new coach, Todd Berry, and the one-back, three-wideout passing offense that replaced the run-oriented wishbone, which Army had used for 16 years, the Black Knights came out throwing from the start.

Quarterback Chad Jenkins completed 5 of his first 6 passes, and with Jenkins accounting for 47 yards on 2 passes, the Black Knights drove 70 yards for the game's first touchdown on their second possession. A reserve running back, Josh Holden, scored on a slithering run along the right side.

But that lead was short-lived as a Boston College backup tailback, William Green, returned the ensuing kickoff 84 yards to the Army 8-yard line. Then, Cedric Washington bolted up the middle to score, and the Eagles were on their way to a 55-17 rout of the Black Knights before a crowd of 37,544.

The 38-point loss matched the worst home defeat ever for Army (0-2), which was playing with only four days off after losing its opener Monday at Cincinnati, 23-17. Army was beaten, 45-7, by Pittsburgh in 1980.

Today's game was close throughout the first half. Had it not been for a pass interception at Army's 32 late in the first quarter and an ill-advised onside kickoff, the Black Knights could have kept it closer. But the interception led to the Eagles going ahead by 14-7. And the onside kick -- following a 27-yard field goal by Brendan Mullen that had trimmed the deficit to 14-10 -- set the stage for a 60-yard Eagles' drive. Mike Sutphin hit his second field goal, from 24 yards out, to provide a 17-10 lead as time expired in the half.

Those 3 points turned out to be the first of 17 scored by the visitors over a span of 37 seconds. Following the second-half kickoff, Boston College quarterback Tim Hasselbeck connected with wide receiver Dedrick Dewalt on the first play for a 75-yard touchdown.

Then, 20 seconds later, Curtis Bolden, a B.C. linebacker, picked off a Jenkins pass on Army's first play of the half and raced down the left sideline untouched for a 22-yard touchdown. The Eagles scored four unanswered touchdowns in the third period to take a 48-10 lead.

The Eagles added a final touchdown late in the fourth period, as did Army. The Black Knights' second touchdown came with two seconds left when Curtis Zervik, the third-string quarterback, passed 12 yards to Clinton Woody, a freshman wide receiver, to cap a 63-yard drive.
''We played two different halves,'' Berry said. ''We should have reacted better in the second half and we've got to make things happen.''

Hasselbeck, a senior, connected on 14 of 21 passes for 256 yards and 3 touchdowns, 2 of them by Dewalt. Hasselbeck's backup, Brian St. Pierre, was no less effective, hitting on 6 of 8 passes for 89 yards. That added up to 335 passing yards to 193 yards by Army. The B.C. quarterbacks did not throw an interception; Jenkins was intercepted twice.
